items.title: Donald Trump broke the law by removing climate change references from USDA websites, lawsuit alleges
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary:
- A lawsuit claims the USDA’s removal of climate change information harms organic farmers.
- The suit was filed by the Northeast Organic Farming Association of New York and environmental groups after the USDA eliminated key webpages.
- Trump’s administration is accused of violating federal laws including FOIA and the Administrative Procedure Act.
- The lawsuit outlines that affected farmers relied on USDA resources for decision-making regarding climate change impacts.
- Previous online tools for assessing climate risks are no longer available, hindering farmers’ ability to adapt to changing conditions.
- The lawsuit also emphasizes issues with funding access for sustainable farming practices.
- The USDA has not commented on the lawsuit, while some webpages were restored earlier due to a different legal ruling.

items.title: Anker’s new USB-C HDMI cable supports 140W fast charging
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Anker has launched the Nano USB-C to HDMI Cable Adapter facilitating high-speed charging and video output.
- Compatible with Thunderbolt 5, it allows 140W power delivery while using an external display.
- Priced at $28.99, the current 3-foot version is set to expand with a 6-foot model in the future.
- While it works with various devices, it does not support portable docking for Nintendo Switch or some Dell, LG, and Samsung monitors due to connector sizing.

items.title: Dark Horse is shutting down its iOS comics app
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Dark Horse Digital service shutting down, affecting iOS comics app support.
- Users must download purchased comics by March 30th, support ends March 31st.
- Digital comics can still be accessed on the Dark Horse Digital website until summer 2025 for registered users.
- Dark Horse will continue to sell ebooks on other platforms, citing changes in consumer preferences.
- Refunds available for 2023 purchases, but iOS app refunds must go through Apple.
- Users reminded they do not own digital books, only a license to them, pointing to issues of digital ownership.

items.title: Microsoft makes Copilot Voice and Think Deeper free with unlimited use
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary:
- Microsoft has made OpenAI’s o1 reasoning model free for all Copilot users.
- Unlimited use of Copilot's Voice and Think Deeper features is now available for everyone.
- The move allows users to engage in extended conversations with Copilot's AI assistant.
- Microsoft previously had limits on these features for free users.
- The changes come after the launch of Copilot in Bing and the revamp of the Copilot Pro subscription, which costs $20 per month.

items.title: Chegg sues Google over AI Overviews
items.author: Sheena Vasani
items.summary:
- Chegg filed a lawsuit against Google on February 24th, claiming that AI-generated summaries hurt its traffic and revenue.
- This lawsuit is regarded as the first antitrust case by a single company over Google's AI Overviews feature.
- Chegg alleges Google leverages its monopoly power to use Chegg's content without compensation, affecting its business model.
- Chegg's CEO stated that the lawsuit addresses broader issues in digital publishing, internet search, and access to educational resources.
- Google argues that its AI Overviews enhance diversity in site traffic on the web, providing billions of clicks daily.

items.title: Tesla reportedly launches FSD in China — or has it?
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Tesla begins to push a software update for Full Self-Driving features in China, marketed as "Urban Road Autopilot Assistance" (URAA).
- URAA guides vehicles on highways and urban roads, assisting with navigation and traffic signals.
- The Chinese version of FSD is reported to be "less capable" than the North American version due to insufficient training data on local roads.
- The update will be available only to vehicles with "HW 4.0" including recent Model Y and Model 3 cars.
- Delays in the rollout may hinder Tesla's competitiveness against Chinese EV makers like BYD and Xiaomi.
- Elon Musk's efforts for regulatory approval in China have faced challenges; plans for a local data center are considered.

items.title: Clicks’ BlackBerry-style keyboard case is coming to Android phones
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- The Clicks keyboard case will soon be available for various Android devices, starting in April 2024.
- It has already sold over 100,000 units for iPhone models since its January 2024 launch.
- Preorders for Android cases begin immediately, with the Google Pixel 9 version priced at $99 until March 21, increasing to $139 thereafter.
- The keyboard case includes customizable functionalities via the Clicks Keyboard mobile app and features backlighting.
- The design allows for keyboard shortcuts and is compatible with USB-C for power, eliminating the need for battery units.

items.title: The new Beeper app combines all of Automattic’s messaging systems
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Beeper has announced a beta update to merge its services with Texts, acquired by Automattic in 2023.
- The new desktop version is based on the Texts desktop app, and the iOS app was developed from scratch.
- Beeper supports messaging across multiple platforms, including WhatsApp and Instagram.
- Plans to support iMessage in the desktop version and introduce features like end-to-end encryption and multiple account support are on the horizon.

items.title: You can get four Apple AirTags for a record low $68
items.author: Quentyn Kennemer
items.summary:
- Apple AirTags are on sale for $67.99 for a four-pack, a savings of approximately $31.
- Single AirTags are available for $22.99 each at various retailers.
- AirTags utilize the Find My network for precise item tracking and have user-replaceable batteries.

items.title: UK Newspapers Unite Against AI Copyright Proposals
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- Major UK newspapers feature the same campaign imagery on their covers to protest government proposals on AI and copyright.
- The campaign, dubbed 'Make It Fair', calls for protection of British creative industries against AI companies using copyrighted work without permission.
- A public consultation period on these proposals closed today, coinciding with the launch of the campaign on December 17th.
- Concerns raised that weakening copyright protections could devastate the UK’s $152 billion creative industry.
- The NMA, including major publications like The Sun and Daily Mail, leads the campaign against these government proposals.

items.title: Xbox’s new Fable game is delayed to 2026
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary:
- Microsoft has delayed the release of its upcoming game Fable to 2026, previously set for 2025.
- Xbox Game Studios chief Craig Duncan announced the delay during an official Xbox podcast, emphasizing the need for more development time.
- Early gameplay footage previews a hero named Humphry, who is drawn out of retirement to confront a threat to Albion.
- Playground Games, known for the Forza Horizon series, is developing the game, promising stunning visuals and engaging gameplay.

items.title: This RC purse redefines fast fashion with a top speed of 9 mph
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Nik Bentel Studio created a leather purse with a built-in remote control car.
- The RC Car Bag can reach a top speed of 9 mph and is designed for minimal obstacles.
- It includes a controller with a 30-foot range, but storage inside is limited.
- Priced at $295, the bag is questioned for its practicality versus fashion statement.
- Future updates could include Bluetooth for smartphone control and more color options.

items.title: The Peloton story: everything you need to know
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Peloton’s oldest bike tablet will be cut off from classes in a few months.
- Peloton’s app now pairs with third-party treadmills for some subscribers.
- CEO Peter Stern explained that no Peloton-branded hardware products are subject to tariffs from China, Mexico, or Canada.
- 2022 was marked by layoffs, gaffes, and negative press for Peloton.
- Peloton recalls its treadmills following a series of accidents.
- The company launches Strength Plus, an audio-based strength training app.
- Peloton partners with Fitbit, offering free access to classes for Fitbit Premium users.
- Reports of a private equity buyout are circulating amidst Peloton's financial struggles and ongoing layoffs.

items.title: Ron Wyden asks for rules about whether you own your digital purchases
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Sen. Ron Wyden urges the FTC to clarify that digital purchases often mean licensing, not ownership.
- Wyden's letter seeks guidance on license duration, transfer rights, and clear communication at the point of sale.
- Recent California law mandates that digital stores disclose licensing terms related to purchases, prompting companies to update their policies.

items.title: YouTube will show fewer ads in ‘interruptive’ slots
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Starting May 12th, YouTube will reduce mid-roll ads considered interruptive and increase ads at natural breaks.
- Automatic ad slots will be added to older videos; creators can choose between automatic and manual placements.
- An internal study found that a mix of automatic and manual ad slots generated five percent more revenue.
- Creators can opt out of automatic placements but may earn less with interruptive ads post-update.

items.title: The Casio Ring Watch is extremely silly, and that’s why I love it
items.author: Victoria Song
items.summary:
- The Casio Ring Watch, priced at $120, is designed to celebrate Casio's 50th anniversary.
- It is a tiny watch that fits on a finger, reminiscent of vintage watch rings from the '80s and '90s.
- The watch offers features like a stopwatch, alarm, and dual timezone but lacks fitness tracking.
- Currently, the ring watch is hard to find on the market, with prices exceeding $300 on eBay.
- Available only in a single size (10.5), it includes spacers for smaller fingers, but larger sizes are not accommodated.
- Users report receiving numerous compliments on the watch, enhancing its appeal beyond practicality.
- The battery lasts around two years without needing charging, making it low maintenance.
- The watch has quirky functionality, allowing discreet time-checking during conversations without being rude.

items.title: How AI PCs are removing barriers to workplace connection
items.author: Shawn Shinneman
items.summary: - AI PCs are playing a crucial role in enhancing workplace connections in the hybrid work environment. - 90% of businesses plan to maintain a hybrid work model, leading to a desire for better interaction among employees. - AI PCs such as Lenovo's ThinkPad X9 and ThinkPad X1 Carbon Gen 13 Aura improve collaboration and productivity. - The technology helps combat isolation by enabling better communication tools and user experiences across different technical capabilities. - Lenovo's AI PCs include features for enhancing user efficiency and addressing physical health concerns like eye strain and poor posture. - AI assistants, like Lenovo AI Now, improve workflow and adapt to user behaviors for enhanced productivity.

items.title: GIGABYTE’s latest AI motherboards push gaming performance forward
items.author: Vox Creative
items.summary:
- The B800 series motherboards debuted at CES on February 25, 2025.
- Designed for Intel B860 and AMD B850 chipsets, enhancing gaming performance.
- Incorporates AI-powered solutions for improved DDR5 memory performance, achieving overclocking up to 9466+ MT/s.
- Features like AI OC model for one-click performance boost and AI-driven PCB design contributing to overall efficiency.
- Premium thermal solutions and DIY-friendly designs included in both AMD B850 and Intel B860 models.
- X3D Turbo Mode available on the AMD B850 for optimized gaming performance with Ryzen processors.
- Offers a variety of models catering to different user needs and aesthetic preferences.

items.title: The future of the internet is likely smaller communities, with a focus on curated experiences
items.author: Edwin Wong
items.summary:
- The modern internet, nearly three decades old, is seen as outdated and in need of evolution.
- As AI rises, the definition of community and human connection is changing, impacting how brands and platforms engage.
- Research by Vox Media and Two Cents Insights shows that consumer power is shifting back, with a demand for more meaningful, authentic connection.
- Key findings include a decline in trust for big platforms, a desire for smaller communities, and an emphasis on content.
- Consumers prefer human-driven engagement over AI and automation, with many favoring intimate, purpose-driven communities.

items.title: Panasonic’s Lumix S1RII full-frame camera captures 8K video
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Panasonic announces Lumix S1RII, an upgrade from the S1R, featuring a new 44.3-megapixel back-side illuminated CMOS sensor.
- Capable of recording 8K video at 30fps, it also supports 5.8K Apple ProRes RAW HQ or ProRes RAW recording.
- Improved autofocus with phase-detect AF and enhanced AI tracking for various subjects.
- Capable of capturing 12-bit RAW stills at up to 40 fps with an electronic shutter.
- Handheld high-resolution mode allows capturing images at 177-megapixels.
- In-body image stabilization improved with 8 stops of shake reduction.
- Expected availability in late March for $3,299.99.

items.title: Silent Hill 2 developer is working with Konami on a mystery game
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary:
- Bloober Team is continuing its partnership with Konami on a new project.
- The new game will be based on Konami's IP but the specific title is not disclosed.
- Bloober Team previously collaborated with Konami on the remake of Silent Hill 2, which received rave reviews and was a commercial success.
- Konami is also developing a non-remake Silent Hill game called Silent Hill F, and a movie adaptation of Silent Hill 2 is in production.

items.title: We can’t quit electric cars — or robotaxis
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- The article discusses the initial excitement around electric vehicles (EVs) and robotaxis that has since waned.
- Experts analyze why EVs continue facing opposition and why automakers are reluctant to abandon them.
- The resurgence of interest in robotaxis as Uber and Lyft revive their plans for automated ride-sharing.
- The episode also covers developments in the fediverse and the rise of platforms like Bluesky and Threads.
- Insights from Evan Prodromou about the ActivityPub protocol and its potential impact on social platforms.

items.title: Trello’s new update helps you manage Slack, email, and everything else
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- Trello is launching new features to turn the app into a universal to-do list, integrating with Slack, email, and Siri.
- A new Inbox column allows users to capture tasks from various platforms to be organized later.
- Features include the ability to forward emails, save Slack messages, and voice input via Siri.
- New calendar view called Trello Planner enables scheduling of emails and tasks, syncing with users’ calendars.
- New features are in beta and will be available to all Trello users in April, focusing on individual productivity.

items.title: Adobe’s new Photoshop app for iPhone is more like the real thing
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- Adobe released a new Photoshop mobile app for iPhone, integrating many desktop features.
- The app is available globally on iPhone, with an Android version to follow later this year.
- Users have access to editing tools like Spot Healing Brush and layers for free, with advanced tools available via subscription.
- Existing Photoshop subscribers can access the mobile app without additional costs.
- The user interface is optimized for mobile, while enhancing the overall experience for creative professionals.

items.title: ‘Tesla Takedown’ wants to hit Elon Musk where it hurts
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Around 50 protesters rallied outside Tesla's Manhattan showroom, part of a nationwide series of protests called #TeslaTakedown.
- The demonstrations are aimed at addressing Elon Musk's influence over the federal government and his controversial actions.
- The protests have expanded significantly, with 65 events planned and grassroots organizational efforts led by groups on Bluesky.
- Protesters aim to hurt Musk financially and socially by persuading people not to buy Tesla vehicles or stocks.
- Tesla's market share has fallen below 50%, and a recent poll shows significant disapproval of Musk's leadership.
- The protests coincide with declining Tesla sales and criticism of Musk's antics, including his links to Donald Trump and perceived authoritarian behavior.
- There have been reports of vandalism against Tesla vehicles during the protests, indicating rising tensions.

items.title: New leaks suggest Samsung’s Z Fold 7 is getting much thinner
items.author: Dominic Preston
items.summary:
- New leaks indicate the Galaxy Z Fold 7 will be just 4.5mm thick when open, making it one of the thinnest foldables.
- The current thinnest foldable, Oppo’s Find N5, is 4.2mm thick, while other competitors range from 4.4mm to 5.8mm.
- The Z Fold 7 will feature an 8.2-inch inner screen, a 6.5-inch outer screen, and a 4,400mAh battery in a thinner design.
- It is expected to be powered by the Snapdragon 8 Elite and include a 200-megapixel main camera.
- The launch is anticipated in July 2025, alongside the Galaxy Z Flip 7.

items.title: Three years later, the Steam Deck has dominated handheld PC gaming
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary:
- The Steam Deck celebrates its third anniversary as a leading handheld gaming PC.
- Valve reported sales of 'multiple millions', with estimates showing Steam Deck surpasses all competitors combined.
- Estimated shipments from 2022 to 2024 include approximately 6 million units, predominantly Steam Decks.
- IDC's data indicates a gradual growth in the handheld gaming market.
- Steam Deck continues to excel in features and compatibility compared to competitors like Asus ROG Ally and Lenovo Legion Go.

items.title: Google Gemini’s AI coding tool is now free for individual users
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- Google has launched a free version of Gemini Code Assist for individual users, aimed at solo developers, students, and freelancers.
- The service allows up to 180,000 code completions per month, significantly higher than competitors like GitHub Copilot, which limits users to 2,000 completions.
- Gemini Code Assist is powered by Google’s Gemini 2.0 AI model and can generate code blocks, provide coding assistance, and support all programming languages in the public domain.
- Developers can interact with the tool using natural language prompts.
- The free tier lacks some advanced features available in paid versions, such as productivity metrics and Google Cloud integrations.

items.title: Microsoft is testing free Office for Windows apps with ads
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary:
- Microsoft is testing a free, ad-supported version of Office apps for Windows, currently available in certain regions like India.
- This version allows access to Word, Excel, and PowerPoint without a Microsoft 365 subscription, but includes persistent side ads and video ads.
- Users must store files in OneDrive, as local storage is disabled, and the version lacks some features compared to the paid version, such as drawing tools in Word and macros in Excel.

items.title: Powerplay 2: Logitech made its magic mousepad cheaper instead of better
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary:
- Logitech is releasing the Powerplay 2 on March 11, priced at $100, which is $20 cheaper than the original.
- The new mousepad features a 15% wider charging area and is thinner at 3.5mm.
- It lacks a built-in wireless mouse receiver and uses a fixed cable instead of USB-C.
- The RGB light in the Logitech G logo has been removed, making the design feel cheaper.
- The new charging coin is not compatible with the original Powerplay mousepad.
- Logitech anticipates retailers will offer bundles after launch, possibly including discounted mice.

items.title: Longer-lasting laptops: the modular hardware you can upgrade and repair yourself
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Growing trend in designing laptops for upgradability and repairability rather than just recycling.
- Framework is a leading example in the modular laptop market, allowing easy upgrades.
- Dell's Alienware faced legal issues over promise of GPU upgrades, highlighting industry challenges.
- Lenovo and other companies are inspired by Framework's success to pursue modular designs.
- Framework's products are mostly manufactured in Taiwan, mitigating tariff impacts on US prices.
- New modular components and future plans for increased product functionality are in the pipeline.

items.title: Everything You Need to Know About Disney, ESPN, and Bob Iger’s Return as CEO
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Disney's streaming strategy is under pressure as the clock is ticking on its effectiveness.
- A crackdown on password sharing for Disney Plus begins in June 2024.
- The merger between Disney Plus and Hulu offers more than just a streaming bundle, reflecting a strategic shift.
- The recent CEO battle between Bob Iger and Bob Chapek highlighted internal conflicts at Disney.
- ESPN is testing a generative AI avatar named FACTS to enhance sports analytics and engagement.
- Disney reported its streaming business has become profitable for the second consecutive quarter, with a profit increase in Q4 2024 to $321 million from $47 million.

items.title: All the news about Nvidia’s RTX 50-series GPUs
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Nvidia has confirmed that the RTX 5080 was affected by a manufacturing issue that left some units missing render output processors (ROPs).
- Affected customers can contact board manufacturers for replacements.
- Previous reports confirmed that the RTX 5090 and RTX 5070 Ti were also affected by the same issue.
- Nvidia's RTX 5070 Ti offers good performance relative to price, aiming to compete with AMD's RX 7900 series.
- A new 'Verified Priority Access' program is being launched by Nvidia to help fans buy RTX 5080 and 5090 FE GPUs.

items.title: Nvidia admits some early RTX 5080 cards are missing ROPs, too
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary:
- Nvidia confirmed that early production builds of the RTX 5080 were affected by a manufacturing issue, missing some render units.
- The affected models include RTX 5090, RTX 5090D, RTX 5070 Ti, and now RTX 5080.
- Less than 0.5% of these GPUs are impacted, with a 4% average performance decrease but no impact on AI and Compute workloads.
- Affected consumers can contact their board manufacturer for replacements.
- The production anomaly has been corrected, and newer cards are not affected.
- The issue was discovered by a Redditor who found their RTX 5080 missing ROPs, and the card will be sent for further investigation.

items.title: Handheld PC Gaming Revolution: Steam Deck and ROG Ally News
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Valve's plans for Steam Machines are becoming clearer.
- Asus ROG Ally X has been reviewed as the best Windows gaming handheld.
- The Steam Deck has evolved into a more refined product ready for the market.
- Lenovo's Legion Go S is introduced as a competitive handheld with SteamOS.
- Discussion on the evolving landscape of handheld gaming with various new competitors.

items.title: Epic Games v. Apple: the fight for the future of the App Store
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Apple must produce 1.3 million documents related to App Store changes by a court deadline.
- Epic Games argues that the fees Apple charges for outside payment links violate a 2021 court order. 
- Only 38 out of 65,000 developers have applied for alternative payment methods approved by Apple. 
- A judge expressed skepticism towards Apple's rationale regarding the implementation of fees for alternative payment links. 
- Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers will hold hearings to further address whether Apple is complying with court orders on payment systems.

items.title: TikTok Ban: Latest Updates on the App's Status in the US
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- TikTok has been restored in the US App Store following a temporary ban.
- President Trump has ordered a 75-day pause on enforcing the TikTok ban starting January 20.
- TikTok's service providers may still face billions in penalties despite restoration.
- Users can now download TikTok from [Apple](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/tiktok/id835599320) and [Google Play](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.zhiliaoapp.musically) after the app's removal due to the initial ban.
- There are ongoing discussions about the future of TikTok, including potential ownership talks involving Oracle and Microsoft.

items.title: The quirky Alarmo clock is no longer exclusive to Nintendo’s online store
items.author: Quentyn Kennemer
items.summary:
* Nintendo's Alarmo clock is now available from third-party retailers such as [Best Buy](https://howl.link/z73qyjwthc940).
* The alarm clock retails for $99.99 and can also be purchased directly from [Nintendo](https://go.skimresources.com/?id=1025X1701640&xs=1&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nintendo.com%2Fus%2Fstore%2Fproducts%2Fnintendo-sound-clock-alarmo-121311%2F) without a subscription (requires a Nintendo account).
* The Alarmo features characters and scenes from classic Nintendo franchises, using motion sensors to wake users more aggressively based on their sleep state.
* It has a 2.8-inch LCD display, illuminated button, and compatibility with sound scenes from various games, with 35 scenes available across five franchises at launch, more to come.

items.title: Trump’s first 100 days: all the news affecting the tech industry
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Elon Musk imposed a deadline for federal workers to document their productivity in response to an email sent by the Office of Personnel Management.
- The email required a report of accomplishments and threatened that failure to respond would be seen as a resignation.
- This directive has caused confusion and raised legal concerns about its appropriateness.
- Apple announced plans to invest $500 billion in the US, part of an effort to mitigate the impact of President Trump's tariffs.
- Apple plans to create 20,000 jobs and build a new factory in Texas over the next four years.
- The SEC concluded its investigation into Robinhood without any enforcement actions, coinciding with the cryptocurrency sector's financial support for political campaigns in the last election cycle.

items.title: The government is still threatening to ‘semi-fire’ workers who don’t answer an email from Elon Musk
items.author: Adi Robertson
items.summary:
- Elon Musk set a deadline for federal workers to reply to his productivity email by February 24th, threatening non-response would be taken as resignation.
- The email's exact demands varied by agency; some instructed staff to ignore it while others enforced compliance.
- President Trump remarked that non-responses could lead to being 'sort of semi-fired', downplaying the conflicting messages from government agencies.
- The situation has prompted legal challenges, with critics condemning the email as an intimidation tactic against federal employees.

items.title: Freedom of speech is ‘on the line’ in a pivotal Dakota Access Pipeline trial
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary:
- A pivotal trial regarding the Dakota Access Pipeline begins, potentially impacting protests in the US and Greenpeace's future.
- Energy Transfers is suing Greenpeace for $300 million, alleging support for unlawful acts by protesters.
- Greenpeace claims the lawsuit is a SLAPP suit aimed at stifling free speech and public participation in activism, while the outcome could threaten its financial viability and over 50 years of activism.

items.title: SpaceX thinks it knows why Starship exploded on its last test flight
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- SpaceX identified the cause of the Starship explosion on January 16, 2025, as fires in the aft section leading to engine shutdowns and a loss of communication.
- The Super Heavy booster successfully completed its mission and was caught mid-air by the launch tower.
- Starship’s second stage encountered issues, resulting in sustained fires that led to the triggering of its self-destruct safety system three minutes after communication was lost.
- An investigation involving multiple agencies is ongoing, and hardware changes have been made for future flights.
- The next Starship test flight is tentatively scheduled for February 28, 2025, pending regulatory approval.

items.title: AT&T and Verizon connect first cellphone-to-satellite video calls
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Verizon and AT&T achieved milestones in cellphone-to-satellite video calls using AST SpaceMobile’s satellites.
- Verizon completed its first video call between a mobile device connected to a satellite and another on its terrestrial network.
- AT&T successfully conducted a video call over its spectrum to a standard smartphone.
- Both companies utilized a constellation of five BlueBird satellites launched in September 2024 for their tests.
- AT&T's initial test had occurred in June 2023.

items.title: Tesla Cybertruck: all the news about Elon Musk’s futuristic pickup truck
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Tesla Cybertruck deliveries began in November 2023, receiving a 5-star crash rating in various categories, including frontal and side crashes.
- The Cybertruck is currently labeled as “America’s bestselling electric pickup truck in 2024,” yet Tesla is offering discounts of up to $2,600, hinting at lower demand than anticipated.
- Tesla recalled around 2,431 Cybertrucks due to inverter issues that could cause a loss of propulsion.

items.title: What to expect from Amazon’s big Alexa event this week
items.author: Jennifer Pattison Tuohy
items.summary:
- Amazon is hosting a press event on **February 26th** in NYC to unveil new features of Alexa and possibly new hardware.
- The revamped Alexa aims to use generative AI and should understand natural speech, context, and can handle multiple requests.
- Speculation includes new Echo devices with updated designs and capabilities for smart home control.

items.title: Annapurna's 2025 lineup of indie games is full of tea and T-poses
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary:
- Annapurna Interactive hosted its first showcase of the year following the mass resignation of its staff.
- The showcase introduced several indie games set to be released in 2025, including:
  - **To a T** by Keita Takahashi, launching on May 28th, 2025.
  - **Morsels**, a creature collector roguelite, with a 2025 release date yet to be confirmed.
  - **Wheel World**, an open-world cycling adventure, set for summer 2025.
  - **Faraway**, featuring a shooting star in a procedurally generated story mode, releasing later this year.
  - **Lushfoil Photography Sim**, launching on April 15th, 2025, featuring true-to-life photography.
  - **Wanderstop**, a tea-themed cozy adventure sim, set to launch on March 11th.
  - **Skin Deep**, a comedic action game, launching on April 30th.
  - **Sayonara Wild Hearts**, now available on PS5 with new updates and game mode.
- Each game showcased unique themes and gameplay mechanics, appealing to various player interests.

items.title: Google Drive gets searchable video transcripts
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Google introduces searchable video transcripts in Google Drive.
- Feature starts rolling out today, expected to complete by March 26, 2025.
- Transcripts appear as timestamped text blocks next to the video, highlighting spoken text in real-time.
- Users can click text in transcripts to navigate to specific moments in videos.
- Transcript availability requires existing captions, which can be auto-generated if not present.

items.title: Anthropic’s new ‘hybrid reasoning’ AI model is its smartest yet
items.author: Alex Heath
items.summary:
- Anthropic has released Claude 3.7 Sonnet, its first hybrid reasoning AI model, enhancing capabilities in math and coding.
- The model is accessible via the Claude app, Anthropic's API, Amazon Bedrock, and Google Cloud’s Vertex AI, costing $3 per million input tokens.
- Claude Code, an agentic coding tool, can edit files, write tests, and integrate with GitHub, enhancing developer collaboration.
- Claude 3.7 demonstrates improved performance in coding, finance, and legal tasks, with a knowledge cut-off of October 2024.
- Developers can influence Claude's responsiveness through a scratchpad, setting specific response times.
- Internal applications include front-end designs and interactive games, with Claude successfully navigating challenges in a Pokémon game.
- The industry trend points towards unified AI models that integrate reasoning with other functionalities.

items.title: All the smart home news, reviews, and gadgets you need to know about
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- The smart home offers convenience, safety, energy efficiency, and fun.
- However, it can be complicated and hard to keep up with rapid developments in the industry.
- The article will provide the latest smart home reviews, guides, and news from major companies like Apple, Amazon, Samsung, and Google.
- New technologies such as Matter, Thread, and UWB will be covered along with existing products.
- Skylight has raised its subscription price from $39 to $79 for its Calendar Max device after enhancing features.

items.title: Elizabeth Holmes Sentenced to 11 Years in Prison for Theranos Fraud
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Elizabeth Holmes has been sentenced to 11 years and 3 months in prison for defrauding investors in Theranos.
- Holmes' sentence was later reduced to 9 years and 7 months due to behavioral considerations.
- She must serve 85% of her sentence regardless of good conduct.
- Holmes will have a supervised release period of 3 years after serving her sentence.
- The sentencing judge, Edward Davila, noted that Holmes' refusal to accept responsibility for her actions influenced the sentence.
